issues.text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal by special leave from the order of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Bombay, is the interpretation of the words life insurance fund as used in paragraph 4 of Part B of the First Schedule to the Life Insurance Corporation Act, No. 31 of 1956

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal by special leave from the order of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Bombay, is the interpretation of the words life insurance fund as used in paragraph 4 of Part B of the First Schedule to the Life

issues.text: The sole question that falls for determination therefore depends on the interpretation of the words life insurance fund

anchor.surface_text: The sole question that falls for determination therefore depends on the interpretation of the words life insurance fund and for that purpose we shall have to consider certain provisions of the Insurance Act as well as of the Act.

issues.text: what the words life insurance fund mean under the Insurance Act and whether they have the same meaning throughout the Act

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore to turn to the Insurance Act first to find out the meaning of the words life insurance fund as given therein and then to see whether the context of cl. d of the said paragraph 4 requires otherwise.

issues.text: the next question is whether the words life insurance fund have any other meaning under the Insurance Act

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the words life insurance fund have any other meaning under the Insurance Act. These words appear in a number of provisions of that Act.

issues.text: Now we come to the last question whether there is anything in the Act which requires that we should give a different meaning to the words life insurance fund in cl. d of the aforesaid 4th paragraph

anchor.surface_text: Now we come to the last question whether there is anything in the Act which requires that we should give a different meaning to the words life insurance fund in cl. (d) of the aforesaid 4th paragraph.

holdings.text: The words 'life insurance fund' as used in cl. (d) of paragraph 4 of Part B of the First Schedule to the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 have the same meaning as that given to them in s.10(2) of the Insurance Act, 1938 read with s.11 and Form D of the Third Schedule to the Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no doubt that the tribunal was right in its conclusion that the words life insurance fund as used in cl. d of the aforesaid 4th paragraph have the same meaning as that given to them in s. 10 2  of the Insurance Act read with s. 1 1 and form D of the Third Schedule to the Insurance Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(10) LIC Act adopts Insurance Act meanings unless context requires otherwise; no such context; consistent usage across Insurance Act provisions; harmonious with Part A/B First Schedule and s.35 LIC Act; avoids absurdity.

holdings.text: There was no surplus in the life insurance fund of the respondent as per Form I of the Fourth Schedule to the Insurance Act; hence no liability under cl. (d) and compensation is Rs. 27,86,658.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case admittedly there was no surplus in form I in the case of the respondent and therefore there

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent's business always showed deficit in Form I; Form I determines surplus/deficit as life insurance fund (Form A) minus net liabilities (Form H); no debit under cl.(d).

holdings.text: The words 'life insurance fund' have a definite meaning under the Insurance Act as the balance arrived at in the revenue account in Form D of the Third Schedule read with ss.10(2) and 11.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt therefore that the words life insurance fund under the Insurance Act have got the meaning assigned to it under s. 10 2  read with s. 1 1 and form D of the Third Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual definition in s.10(2); revenue account in Form D per s.11(c); balance enters balance sheet Form A; excludes share capital etc.

holdings.text: The words 'life insurance fund' do not have any other meaning under the Insurance Act different from that in s.10(2).

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore reject the contention on behalf of the appellant that the words life insurance fund have any meaning other than that assigned to them in s. 10 2  of the Insurance Act so far as that Act is concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of ss.56(2), 58(3), Reg.7 Part I First Schedule shows no departure; marginal notes do not control; plural 'funds' grammatical only.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the context of the LIC Act requiring a different meaning for 'life insurance fund' in cl.(d) from the Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: Now we come to the last question whether there is anything in the Act which requires that we should give a different meaning to the words life insurance fund in cl. d of the aforesaid 4th paragraph.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(10) applies unless context otherwise requires; rationale of cl.(d) mirrors s.49(1) Insurance Act for past surplus allocation; consistent with Parts A/B; s.35 avoids inconsistency.

holdings.text: Assets kept invested under s.27(1) Insurance Act to cover deficit do not become part of the life insurance fund unless included in revenue account Form D.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that form D of the Third Schedule includes an item other income but that does not mean that any sum kept invested by an insurer for the purposes of s. 27 1 in order to cover the deficit

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.27(1) for policyholder protection/safety; not automatic inclusion; respondent's funds never in Form D; s.27(6) trust separate.

holdings.text: Cl. (d) is meant for cases with undistributed surplus per Form I under Part B; implements s.49(1) Insurance Act by debiting 96% as liability.

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt that the provision in cl. (d) is related to the provision in s. 49 (1) of the Insurance Act. We have already referred to that section and it requires that 92 1/2% of the surplus in form I shall be kept for the policy- holders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 96% debit mirrors policyholder share in past surplus; no surplus, no debit; distinguishes future via cl.(b).

holdings.text: Appellant's interpretation of 'life insurance fund' as total assets minus liabilities under cls.(a),(c) rejected; leads to absurdity and inconsistency with s.35 LIC Act.

anchor.surface_text: Besides we are of opinion that if the words life insurance fund in cl. d are to be given the meaning for which the appellant is contending there will be a clear inconsistency between cl. d and s. 35 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would allow more recovery via s.35 application; share capital absurdly included for Indian cos; inconsistent totals.

holdings.text: The appeal is dismissed with costs to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the appeal must fail. We therefore dismiss the appeal with costs to the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upheld tribunal's award based on correct interpretation.

justification_sets.label: Form D, Third Schedule, Insurance Act, 1938 support

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the appeal must fail. We therefore dismiss the appeal with companyts to the respondent.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed upholding the Life Insurance Tribunal's award of compensation at Rs. 27,86,658 to the respondent
